title: Euclidean Space
description: This is a fully-playable video game programmed entirely in Desmos (with the exception of the asteroid and space ship images being created in MS Paint). It even has a switch you can flip to play on the Desmos mobile app. Seriously. Try it out. The game is basically a space-themed flappy bird with extra lives and a gradually increasing difficulty. Think you can get to 100 points? This was only the 10th graph on this page, and it's still unbeat in awesomeness. This was also the first project where I really realized what Desmos can do, including the neat fact that it is Turing complete. Background music and space ship design by Aiden Chiasson.

title: Conway's Game of Life
description: Arguably the coolest Turing complete system (well, except maybe Desmos) ever created. This was on my Desmos bucket list ever since I found out Desmos is Turing complete. I suppose the next thing to do is to make Desmos on Conway's Game of Life. That might be a tad more difficult, though.

title: Mandelbrot Set 2.0
description: Version two of this fractal had several improvements which, in combination with the fact that the Mandelbrot set is simply awesome, has given this graph a very high awesomeness score. In contrast to version one, this graph uses actual recursion, making it way more efficient and giving it way fewer equations. A better rainbow system was also incorporated along with a variable recursion depth.

title: Desmos Demos Data
description: This is a snapshot of the graph found in the Data tab of this page from when it was first created. The funny thing is, originally, I was going to embed a Power BI dashboard into this page to show all the Desmos Demos data visuals. What I didn't know was that to do this, you need a paid "pro" account, so I had to find an alternative data visualization tool. And what better tool for summarizing data about Desmos graphs than Desmos itself?

title: Randomly Generated Sierpinski Triangle
description: Inspired by "Chaos Game - Numberphile" by Numberphile (Ben Sparks) [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=kbKtFN71Lfs]

title: Randomly Generated Sierpinski Tetrahedron
description: This is simply the 3D equivalent of the randomly generated Sierpinski triangle.

title: Hilbert Curve
description: This is a space-filling curve, meaning that the limit of this curve will hit every point in the square, even points like (pi/4,pi/4) which will never be hit by any finite level Hilbert curve. In simple words, it means it will keep spreading out to cover more space. Most people count Hilbert curves as fractals, though by some definitions it is not.

title: Binary Image
description: Inspired by the video "The 'Everything' Formula - Numberphile" by Numberphile (Matt Parker) [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=_s5RFgd59ao]

title: Mandelbrot Set
description: I love fractals, and the Mandelbrot set is one of the coolest ones out there. I knew I had to graph it in Desmos.

title: Mandelbrot Set 3.0
description: Despite being the third version of this fractal, it is actually slightly worse performance-wise, which is why it's much lower on the awesomeness scale. For this version, I used the (at the time) new complex mode to replace the pointwise opperations with more elegant, but slower, complex-number-wise opperations.

title: Newton's Fractal 2.0
description: Version two of this graph is simply a more efficient version of Newtons fractal.

title: Newton's Fractal
description: Inspired by the video "Newton’s fractal (which Newton knew nothing about)" by 3Blue1Brown [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=-RdOwhmqP5s]

title: Landscape Generator
description: Inspired by the video "Maps: Fractals, Tectonics and the Fourth Dimension" by Fractal Philosophy [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=7xL0udlhnqI]

title: Stereographic Projections
description: Inspired by the video "What if we define 1/0 = ?? | Möbius transformations visualized" by Mathemaniac [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=hhI8fVxvmaw]

title: Gaussian Primes
description: Inspired by the video "Gaussian Primes Visually" by TheGrayCuber [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=PkWY3fLy4oI&t=421s]

title: Thomae Function
description: This function is continuous on all irrational numbers and discontinuous on all rational numbers. Interestingly, an opposite function (continuous on rationals, discontinuous on irrationals) has been proven to not exist.

title: Weierstrass Function
description: This function is continuous everywhere, but differentiable nowhere, proving that despite the inverse being true, continuity does not imply differentiability.

title: Mandelbrot^3
description: What happens when you change z^2+c to z^3+c in the Mandelbrot set? This.

title: Fermat Contest Scores (2023)
description: This was the year that I competed in the Fermat contest. When the results came out, I tried to find a good graph showing the distribution of people's scores. I couldn't find one, so I built my own.

title: MATH One-Liner
description: For some calculus assignment, I had to prove some property using a recursively-defined function. It didn't matter what the base function was, as long as it was continuous and bounded, so I spent an unnecessary amount of time constructing this function to use for the proof.

title: Ghost
description: This is the oldest graph on this page. Before this, I had messed around with random Desmos functions and how they could be used to create neat patterns, but I had never tried to make anything worth sharing. Then, nearing Haloween, my math teacher gave us a fun assignment to create something Haloween-esque in Desmos. This was the result.

title: Swirling Orbs
description: Inspired by the video "But what is a Fourier series? From heat flow to drawing with circles | DE4" by 3Blue1Brown [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=r6sGWTCMz2k]

title: Planar Equation from 3 Points
description: This came about from attempting a 3D render in Desmos and needing a way to detect which side of a 3D plane a given point is on.

title: Planar Equation from 3 Vectors
description: Halfway through a linear algebra lecture, as I was learning about the vector equation of a plane, I thought, "this would make a good Desmos graph."

title: Decay of Protactinium 231
description: I made this graph to use in a physics lab report. It's not particularly awesome, but I figured I'd stick it here since I have it.
